notes: Classic very low-mass arm. The fixed headshell version of the Improved S2. Ideal for high-compliance cartridges like Shure V15 III.
The classic low-mass arm with a removable headshell, making it slightly heavier than the fixed version. Still best for high-compliance cartridges.
A benchmark for budget to mid-priced tonearms for decades. One-piece cast aluminum arm tube. Medium mass.
Legendary heavy-mass arm from Technics with variable dynamic damping. Excellent for low-compliance MCs like the Denon DL-103.
A very popular and versatile modern medium-to-heavy S-shaped arm. Features oil damping.
The classic tonearm for the Linn Sondek LP12. Known for its rhythmic and dynamic performance. Medium mass.
A legendary heavy-mass arm, considered one of the best ever for low-compliance MCs. Built like a tank.
A popular low-mass arm from Pro-Ject, featuring a one-piece carbon fiber armtube and headshell.
Iconic 'quad-master' ultra-low-mass arm from the 70s. Instantly recognizable design.
The legendary ultra-low-mass champion. Made with thin carbon fiber tubes. Fragile but a perfect match for extremely high-compliance cartridges like the ADC XLM/ZLM.
Classic heavy-mass S-shaped arm, ideal for Ortofon's own SPU cartridges.
A modern reference tonearm. One-piece magnesium arm tube. Known for its neutrality and detail retrieval.
VPI's 9-inch unipivot tonearm. A popular choice on their turntables. Low-to-medium mass.
Represents a typical modern, budget-friendly S-shaped arm. Medium mass.
A highly regarded unipivot arm known for its stability and excellent sound. Medium mass.
A classic British unipivot tonearm. Low mass, often seen as a great partner for Decca cartridges.
A vintage Japanese arm famous for its 'double knife edge' bearing. Medium-heavy mass.
The classic stock tonearm on many Thorens turntables like the TD 160. Medium mass.
Linn's reference tonearm. Built with titanium and extremely tight tolerances. A modern classic.
Represents the typical medium-mass arm found on classic Dual automatic turntables.
A classic and highly regarded Japanese tonearm, known for its precision and 'on-the-fly' VTA adjustment.
Legendary British unipivot arm. Cherished for its musicality and 'boogie factor'. Famously has no anti-skate.
A well-regarded medium-mass tonearm from the 90s, often seen as a competitor to the Rega RB300.
A modern carbon-fiber tonearm with a gimbal bearing, designed to be rigid and low-resonance. Medium-heavy.
A high-end German tonearm known for its precision engineering and Cardanic bearing. Medium mass.
The modern entry-level Rega arm, found on Planar 1 and Planar 2. Shares geometry with the RB3xx series.
A legendary and highly-regarded Scottish tonearm, often considered a peer to the Linn Ittok. Known for its fluid, musical sound.
A classic high-end tonearm famous for its one-piece titanium armtube. Known for its strength, stability, and clean sound.
Mobile Fidelity's 10-inch tonearm, developed with Allen Perkins of Spiral Groove. Medium mass.
A legendary and innovative low-mass tonearm from the late 70s. Famous for its fluid damping and superb sound quality.
The original classic 12-inch arm, ideal for low-compliance cartridges like the Ortofon SPU.
A modular system with interchangeable armwands (e.g., EPA-A501H for high mass). Base effective mass is for the EPA-A501M wand.
A highly-regarded modern unipivot tonearm with exceptional stability and 'on-the-fly' VTA adjustment.
Rega's former reference arm, known for extremely tight bearing tolerances and a polished, resonance-controlled armtube.
A legendary Japanese 12-inch high-mass tonearm, prized for its dynamic and powerful sound with low-compliance MCs.
Modern Thorens tonearm with magnetic anti-skating, found on their higher-end turntables.
A high-quality vintage arm from Audio-Technica with dynamic damping.
A highly-regarded British tonearm, modified from a Rega base. Known for its superb musicality and fluid sound.
Classic 'S-shaped' Denon tonearm with dynamic damping, often paired with the DP-series turntables.
A modern classic inspired by vintage broadcast arms. Medium mass, excellent for Ortofon SPUs and other low-compliance carts.
A high-end vintage arm from Sony's golden era, featuring a carbon fiber tube.
A unique vintage arm where the entire carbon fiber tube could be swapped for different effective masses. Medium mass is for the standard wand.
Iconic design with a golf ball suspended in silicone fluid for damping. A 'damped unipivot'.
Another classic British ultra-low-mass unipivot arm, a direct competitor to the Hadcock and Infinity Black Widow.
The classic 10-inch studio tonearm from EMT, designed for their TSD series cartridges.
A unique vintage arm with a pivoting headshell designed to eliminate tracking error. A complex but fascinating design.
A classic linear tracking tonearm that uses a quartz rod and rides on a track. Extremely low mass.
A modern, high-precision German tonearm with a dual-layer carbon fiber armtube.
A legendary and very expensive servo-controlled linear tracking tonearm.
A highly regarded Japanese unipivot tonearm with oil damping. Known for its clean and musical sound.
A low-mass unipivot from Grace, an alternative to the G-707 with a removable headshell.
A legendary, ultra-high-end Swiss tonearm. Extremely rare and revered for its precision and sound quality.
The tonearm on the modern, audiophile-oriented Technics SL-1200GR. A solid medium-mass performer.
The infamous stock arm on the classic Lenco L75. Very high mass, with vertical V-block bearings that often need replacing.
Roksan's unipivot tonearm, known for a lively, engaging, and musical presentation.
A unique unipivot design from speaker manufacturer Magnepan. Low mass.
A well-built vintage Japanese tonearm, often paired with their own high-output MC cartridges.
Same as Mayware Formula IV. Ultra-low-mass unipivot arm.
A very high-quality, heavy-mass Japanese tonearm from the 70s. Superb engineering.
A legendary and rare high-end arm, also known as 'The Arm' by Sumiko. Designed by David Fletcher.
A modern high-end tonearm featuring a unique tri-point bearing. Medium mass.
Represents the typical medium-heavy stock arm on vintage Pioneer turntables.
Low Mass Fixed headshell version. A very light arm made of carbon fiber, ideal for high-compliance cartridges.
A later, 'Low Cost' version of the famous 774 arm. A straight, low-mass arm that was a great performer for its price.
Pro-Ject's 12-inch reference unipivot tonearm. Medium-heavy mass.
A popular and well-made vintage Japanese tonearm. Solid, reliable medium-mass performer.
The original, heavier Series II arm. Medium mass, a great match for a wider range of cartridges than the later 'Improved' version, including the Denon DL-103.
A unique bi-axis tonearm with separate arms for horizontal and vertical movement, designed for exceptional tracking.
A high-performance modern Rega arm, featuring a tapered armtube and extremely low-tolerance bearings. Found on the Planar 8.
A classic, affordable, and well-performing S-shaped tonearm. A popular choice for many turntable projects.
Linn's entry-level tonearm for many years. A solid, reliable performer with medium mass.
VPI's 12-inch reference unipivot tonearm. Medium mass, excellent stability and sound.
A modern, high-precision 9-inch tonearm from Ortofon. Very low mass despite the removable headshell, making it versatile.
A high-quality vintage arm from AT's professional line. Medium-heavy mass.
A rare and beautiful 12-inch unipivot tonearm from Grace with a wooden armtube.
A very high-end vintage arm from Micro Seiki, known for its superb build quality and sonic performance.
A lower-mass version of the famous SAEC arms, suitable for higher compliance cartridges.
A long-running and successful tonearm from Roksan, known for its clever design and engaging sound.
A modern, reference-level American tonearm, famous for its precision VTA adjustment tower.
A simplified version of the reference Series V, offering a large portion of its performance at a lower price point.
A 9-inch version of the legendary 4Point tonearm, which uses a unique 4-point bearing system for unipivot-like freedom and gimbal-like stability.
A popular unipivot arm often bundled with Nottingham Analogue turntables. Known for its steady, musical presentation.
The stock arm on the RPM 9 turntable. A conical carbon fiber tube over an aluminum core for stiffness and damping.
A legendary tonearm with a unique magnetic thread bearing. Prized for its natural and effortless sound.
An early and influential carbon fiber unipivot design from the British speaker manufacturer.
A classic Danish unipivot tonearm with interchangeable armwands for different effective masses. This is for the standard light wand.
A high-quality tonearm found on Luxman's high-end turntables from the 70s and 80s.
The classic budget reference arm, predecessor to the RB202/220. Found on the original Planar 2.
A common tonearm from the Czech manufacturer, found on many vintage turntables from the Eastern Bloc.
A vintage 12-inch professional studio tonearm from Sony.
A well-regarded, affordable vintage tonearm from Jelco. Medium-heavy mass.
A heavily modified Rega arm from Michell Engineering. The armtube is bead-blasted and perforated, and the wiring is upgraded.
A classic 12-inch tonearm for professional use, a direct competitor to the SME 3012.
A long-running mid-tier Linn tonearm, positioned between the Basik/Krane and the Ekos.
VPI's modern high-end gimbal-bearing tonearm, an alternative to their classic unipivots.
A light-to-medium mass gimbal-bearing arm from Grace.
A classic medium-mass tonearm from Sumiko, made by Jelco. A superb and reliable performer.
A more affordable but still very high-quality tonearm from legendary manufacturer Fidelity Research.
An early, low-mass tonearm from the Scottish company that went on to make the PU2 and PU3.
A very popular carbon fiber tonearm from Micro Seiki, known for its clean aesthetics and sound.
